questions.neutral: Looks like you needed a pause - that right?

hobby.message: You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Needed a break from the building.
Been too chaotic lately, especially after the blackout.
I fold paper to keep focused. Just something simple.
Had to set it aside yesterday—too many interruptions.
Yeah, just decompressing.
Origami is my way to unwind—folding helps me settle my thoughts.
Yesterday was a mess in my block after the BCI crash.
Hard to do anything precise with all that noise.
Guess it’s not always relaxing lately.
Pause, yes. Folding origami is my thing—makes the chaos shrink.
Used to spend hours shaping tricky forms just to clear my head.
But after the BCI blackout, my building’s been loud and tense.
Tough concentrating with neighbors arguing over access.
It’s odd, not having any scores running in the background now.
Couldn’t even finish one modular piece.
Definitely needed this. I always turn to origami, especially when things spiral.
I like complex models—cranes, tessellations, even polyhedra from office scraps.
Last week, during the BCI blackout, I tried to work on a starlight fold.
The building was in constant motion—elevators shutting, people upset about access.
Paper tore; hands too jittery. Never finished that fold.
Someone came by needing help while I was folding.
Funny, the hobby became less about paper, more about managing real-life tangles.
Yeah, it’s been overwhelming. I usually retreat to origami—something I picked up during my engineering training.
I track modular forms and folding ratios, just for the mental precision.
After that citywide BCI blackout, it was impossible to focus—my neighbors needed help, halls crowded with complaints.
I tried folding a star pattern from an old memo envelope, but the tension made my hands unsteady.
Honestly, the paper was almost a comfort object, something normal when routines vanished.
People forget how dependent we were on those scores until they’re gone.
Had to switch from folding to running messages for neighbors, troubleshooting access.
It’s strange—my little hobby became another casualty of system failure, at least for now.
hobby_answer: A few. Not many lately.
Paper's harder to find than it was.
City's been...disruptive since the blackout.
Feels like everyone is watching everyone.
Easier to keep things simple now.
Yeah, I folded a couple last week.
Mostly just cranes. Easier models.
With the blackout, quiet time's rare.
Neighbors come by more, less privacy.
I keep my origami stuff stashed, just in case.
Can’t focus with all the changes.
I still make cranes, yes. Made one yesterday.
It’s calming, good for stress—normally.
Since the blackout, building's chaotic. Hard to relax.
People come to my door with access issues.
Origami helps, but it’s different. Distracted hands show more mistakes.
Paper's in short supply since deliveries stalled.
I hope things stabilize soon.
Lots of cranes, actually. Helps when things are out of control.
I tried a star modular form. Paper tore—hands too shaky after the blackout.
My neighbors kept interrupting—access problems everywhere.
Spent the night running messages, not folding.
It’s odd, missing my own routine like that.
Used to fold for focus, but now it's for comfort.
Feels like the city is folding in on itself.
Weird, but I carry cranes in my pocket for luck.
Definitely—folders habit. Made cranes from Council envelopes during the blackout.
When the BCI went dark, our block turned frantic.
Paper’s oddly precious now, since normal supply is unreliable.
I fold in the kitchen for light, but people bang on my door, needing help.
Mrs. Petrov needed to reach her son—I ran messages up three flights.
Wasn't safe to have unfinished models lying around. Someone might read too much into it.
I started origami for order, now it feels like improvising under surveillance.
Funny how a tiny paper crane feels defiant now.
Guess folding and hiding at the same time might be my new specialty.
